abstract.text: This article describes the KeyboardKit dictation engine.

inlineContent.text: Dictation can be used to let users enter text by speaking instead of typing on the keyboard.

Dictation can be hard to implement in a keyboard, where microphone access is unavailable. KeyboardKit therefore provides dictation-specific tools that lets you add dictation to both an app and its keyboard extension.
ðŸ‘‘
unlocks dictation services for app- and keyboard-based dictation. Information about Pro features can be found at the end of this article.
KeyboardKit has a
namespace that contains dictation-related types.
This namespace doesnâ€™t contain protocols, open classes or types of higher importance.
KeyboardKit has an observable
class that handles dictation state, such as the currently dictated text, in which application dictation was started, etc. as well as observable properties to visualize an ongoing dictation.
KeyboardKit automatically creates an instance of this class and injects it into
, then keeps the context updated during dictation.
In KeyboardKit, a
can perform dictation where microphone access is available, while a
can initialize a dictation operation from a keyboard extension, by opening the main app.
KeyboardKit doesnâ€™t have a standard dictation service. Instead, it injects a disabled service into
until you register a custom instance or register a KeyboardKit Pro license key.
Dictation works differently in apps, where microphone access is available, and in keyboard extensions, where mic access is unavailable.

content.text: How to perform dictation in an app

inlineContent.text: You can use a
to perform dictation where microphone access is available.
To start dictation in an app, just call
and observe the
to see if dictation is started, to get and show the dictated text, to detect any errors, etc.
A
can call
to ask for user permissions. You can call it manually as well, before starting the operation, to avoid interruption.
Since dictation may stop at any time, e.g. due to silence, a
should describe how to access the dictated result.

content.text: How to perform dictation in a keyboard extension

inlineContent.text: You can use a
to perform dictation in a keyboard extension, where the microphone is unavailable.
Keyboard-based dictation must open the app to start dictation or open an audio bridge, then write the dictated text to shared storage and return to the keyboard to process the result.
This can be tricky to set up, but KeyboardKit Pro lets you configure this in a few, simple steps.

iOS 17 caused a way to return to the keyboard from the main app to stop working. Thereâ€™s another way to achieve this, but Apple rejects any apps that use it. Until a workaround is found, you must ask your users to tap the back arrow to return to the keyboard.
unlocks services that let you setup and perform dictation with very little code.
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks a dictation
that lets you visualize a dictation, using any visualizer like a
This screen will automatically fade in when a dictation is started, if you use the Pro keyboard dictation view modifiers. It can be styled with a
, which can be applied with the
view modifier.
A
can be used to visualize an ongoing dictation operation as a collection of vertical, animating bars.
The view can be styled with a
, which can be applied with a
view modifier.
You can change the number of bars, the colors & thickness of the bars, etc. You can also implement your own visualizer, to customize how the dictation operation is presented to the user.
See the
article for more information about how styling is handled in KeyboardKit.
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks a
that can be used in the main app, and a
that can be used to initialize a dictation operation from within a keyboard extension.
The speech recognizer that is used by KeyboardKit Pro supports the following languages:
If you want to use dictation with other languages, you must implement a custom recognizer.
This article describes how to set up a dictation that starts in a keyboard extension and is performed in the app, using KeyboardKit Pro.
Before you can start dictation, you must add these keys to your appâ€™s
, otherwise the app will crash at runtime:
To share data between your app and keyboard extension, you must setup a shared app group for both targets:
While a keyboard will immediately see data from the app, the app may experience delays if Full Access is disabled for the keyboard.
To make it possible for the keyboard to open the app, you must set up a deep link URL scheme for the app target:

content.text: Step 4. Create a keyboard dictation configuration

inlineContent.text: The next step is to create an app-specific
, using the App Group ID and deep link that we just set up.
Make sure to add this configuration file to both the main app target and the keyboard extension, so that both targets can use it.

content.text: Step 5. Set up dictation in the keyboard extension

inlineContent.text: To configure dictation for the
keyboard extension

with the app-specific config we just set up:

content.text: Step 6. Set up dictation in the main application

inlineContent.text: To configure dictation for the
main app
, first register your KeyboardKit Pro license key, as described in the
article, then create a
with the app-specific config and apply it to the appâ€™s root view:
The keyboard dictation view modifier has an overlay parameter that defines the view to show while dictation is active. You can use the Pro dictation
with any of the built-in dictation visualizers, or a completely custom view.
The Pro keyboard dictation view modifier requires a
, which is a protocol that decouples KeyboardKit from the Speech framework, to avoid apps from having to specify dictation permissions when not using speech recognition.
Instead, just add this speech recognizer code to your app, then inject an instance of the class into the keyboard dictation view modifier.

code: try await startDictation(with: config, resultHandler: nil)
guard let recognizer = setupSpeechRecognizer(for: config) else { throw Dictation.ServiceError.missingSpeechRecognizer }
guard let request = setupSpeechRecognizerRequest() else { throw Dictation.ServiceError.missingSpeechRecognitionRequest }
func handleTaskResult(_ result: SFSpeechRecognitionResult?, error: Error?) {

inlineContent.text: You can now start dictation in your keyboard by triggering
or by calling
If everything is correctly configured, the keyboard should open the app to start dictation. When the user returns to the keyboard, it will automatically send the dictated text to the text field.
You can override the controller
to customize how the keyboard handles the dictated text.

In a DocumentGroup-based app, the .keyboardDictation modifier only works when a document is open. Instead, check if isDictationStartedByKeyboard. If itâ€™s true, present a sheet or modal and add .keyboardDictationOnAppear to its root view.
Once dictation is done, the app should return to the keyboard to let it handle the dictated text.
KeyboardKit Pro used to have a
to automatically navigate back to the keyboard, but this stopped working in iOS 17. A new implementation that worked great was then rejected by Apple, due to using private APIs.
KeyboardKit canâ€™t add this code, since it would cause
all
apps to be rejected. To add a custom back navigation implementation, you can inherit
and override
See the
for the implementations that were previously used. Although they may be rejected, they may give some inspiration.
